awd_titl_txt: The Role of Individual and Social Networks in the Formation and Change of Beliefs
awd_abstract_narration:
One unique feature of human thought is the development and maintenance of beliefs.  People carry with them an enduring sense of what is true or false, and whether or not things exist in the world.  Beliefs are central to what it means to be human.  The nature of human beliefs -- their structure, function, and change -- has been the subject of study across many fields of science over many decades.  Past theories and research have approached the subject in two distinct ways.  One, most common in the behavioral and cognitive sciences, is to understand how a single person's network of beliefs relate to one another.  Another, most common in the social and economic sciences, is to understand how one person's beliefs are related to the beliefs of other people in one's social network.  All of these efforts to understand the nature of beliefs are motivated by important broader impacts.  For example, public health campaigns aim to change beliefs, and ultimately behaviors, in service of the health and welfare of society.  The aim of this project is to develop a new theoretical framework that integrates understanding of belief networks at both the individual and social levels.  One expected outcome is a better understanding of why some beliefs are resistant to change while others are not.

This project adopts a network perspective to study why some beliefs are more resistant to change than others. Drawing from psychology, sociology, economics, computer science, and statistical physics, a unifying theoretical framework is developed.  The premise of the model is that network dynamics of beliefs follow similar principles at the individual and at the social level --  that people are motivated to reduce dissonance (energy) both in their own belief network and in their social networks.  The model provides novel predictions about how networks of beliefs on individual and social levels jointly affect belief's resistance to change. The model is tested in a longitudinal survey conducted in four waves, allowing an assessment of belief dynamics over time. An experimental manipulation is introduced before the third wave, allowing for the assessment of potential interventions.  The data analyses rely on advanced statistical models including statistical physics modeling, network modeling, structural equation modeling, and multilevel modeling.  The project will advance basic knowledge by integrating previously disconnected literatures on individual and social beliefs in a single theoretical framework, and developing and testing qualitative and quantitative predictions about the joint effects of individual and social network structures on belief change over time.  The research will contribute to a foundation of knowledge that informs the design of educational interventions aimed at increasing scientific knowledge in the general population.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Beliefs are fundamental to human thought. They shape how we perceive the world, discern truth, and navigate daily decisions. Historically, researchers have approached this in two ways: by examining how beliefs within an individual are interconnected and by exploring how beliefs spread and interact within social groups. This project combines these perspectives into a unified theory, offering new insights into how individual and social networks of beliefs jointly affect belief's resistance to change. 

This project takes a network perspective to explore why some beliefs are more resistant to change than others. It posits that individual beliefs are not isolated but evolve and shift together with related beliefs within a network. The central premise is that belief networks follow similar dynamic principles at both individual and social levels—people strive to reduce dissonance within their personal belief networks and their social networks. This theory identifies three types of dissonance: personal (conflicts between own beliefs), social (conflicts between personal beliefs and the perceived beliefs of others), and external (conflicts between social beliefs and the actual beliefs of others). Using data from two large longitudinal survey studies, we find support for our theoretical assumptions and predictions. The empirical results confirmed the existence of three distinct types of dissonances (personal, social, and external), aligning with the theoretical assumptions. The results also show that attention directed at dissonance significantly influenced belief updating and network dynamics. For example, higher attention to social dissonance resulted in decreased variation in social beliefs and closer alignment between personal and social beliefs, implying increased influence of social networks on individual beliefs. 

The theory also explains diverse belief dynamics phenomena parsimoniously through the differences in attention to different dissonances in personal, social, and external parts of belief networks. These phenomena include group consensus (alignment of beliefs among individuals), group polarization (different segments of the population hold extreme and opposing beliefs), group radicalization (group interaction leads to more extreme group beliefs), and minority influence (the ability of a small subset to influence the majority). 

Beliefs underlying individual choices can have important societal consequences, preventing adequate mitigation of climate change, using GM to develop sufficient food for the growing population, or causing deaths of preventable infectious diseases. This project sheds light on why some beliefs are particularly difficult to change and provides insights for designing educational programs aimed at increasing scientific knowledge in the general population. For instance, focusing on how people resolve personal and social dissonance could help them reconsider entrenched but erroneous beliefs.
